sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying ring
message_1: A physics student needs to determine the magnetic field strength at the center of a circular loop of wire with a radius of 0.1 meters and carrying a current of 2 amperes.
message_2:
To determine the magnetic field strength at the center of a circular loop of wire, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a current-carrying loop:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * R)

where B is the magnetic field strength, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current in the loop, and R is the radius of the loop.

Given the radius R = 0.1 meters and the current I = 2 amperes, we can calculate the magnetic field strength:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A) / (2 * 0.1 m)

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm) / 0.2 m

B ≈ (8 * 3.14159 * 10^(-7) Tm) / 0.2 m

B ≈ 1.25664 × 10^(-5) T

So, the magnetic field strength at the center of the circular loop of wire is approximately 1.25664 × 10^(-5) Tesla.
